Modest modulation on the spin states of Co3O4 nanoframe through vanadium doping for solid-state rechargeable Zn-air/iodide hybrid batteries Yanli Niu Writing – original draft Project administration Funding acquisition Wenze Zhang Methodology Investigation Data curation Mingyang Xu Methodology Investigation Formal analysis Data curation Xiaozhen Li Software Methodology Investigation Formal analysis Data curation Linpo Li Writing – original draft Supervision Project administration Funding acquisition Formal analysis ⁎ Henan Engineering Research Center of Design and Recycle for Advanced Electrochemical Energy Storage Materials, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Henan Normal University, Xinxiang 453007, China Henan Engineering Research Center of Design and Recycle for Advanced Electrochemical Energy Storage Materials School of Materials Science and Engineering Henan Normal University Xinxiang 453007 China Henan Engineering Research Center of Design and Recycle for Advanced Electrochemical Energy Storage Materials, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Henan Normal University, Xinxiang 453007, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The rational construction of bifunctional air cathode electrocatalysts with high intrinsic reversibility and durability is critical for practical applications of rechargeable solid Zn-air batteries (ZABs). Unlike traditional nanomorphology construction methods, this work focus on the enhancement of intrinsic catalytic properties by heteroatom vanadium doping strategy to modulate the spin state of Co3+ ions active sites at the octahedral sites of spinel Co3O4. The magnetic measurements and the theoretical calculation consistently reveal that V atom incorporation induce the spin state transition of Co3+ from low spin state (LS, t 2 g 6 e g 0 ) to intermediate spin state (IS, t 2 g 5 e g 1 ), and reduces the energy gap between the Co 3d and O 2p band centers, which balance the adsorption/desorption of oxygen intermediates and further enhance the oxygen reaction kinetics. Consequently, the optimized V-Co3O4 demonstrated a small potential gap value of 0.74 V between the ORR half-wave potential and the OER potential at 10 mA m−2. More importantly, the introduction of KI in solid-state electrolyte provides a more thermodynamically favorable pathway. Thereby, the assembled ZAB displays excellent long-term durability (180 h), offering a promising power source for the next-generation electronics. This work advances a feasible design concept to tune catalytic activity for ZABs by optimizing the spin states and developing novel solid-state electrolytes. Keywords Vanadium doping Spin states Bifunctional air cathode Solid-state electrolytes Zn-air batteries Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction A wide range of energy conversion and storage devices, varying from fuel cells to metal-air batteries, have been developed to address the energy crisis and environmental challenges [1,2]. In particular, rechargeable aqueous Zn-air batteries (ZABs) are drawing significant attention because of the advantages regarding high theoretical energy density (1086 Wh Kg−1, greatly surpassing lead-acid batteries (∼40 Wh kg−1) and lithium-ion batteries (∼300 Wh Kg−1)), inherent safety, environmental friendliness and excellent affordability [3–5]. Despite the noteworthy superiorities, unsatisfactory energy efficiencies and large overpotential associated with oxygen redox reactions greatly hinder their practical application [6,7]. Additionally, owing to the half-open configuration of ZABs, the unavoidable water loss from the electrolyte would significantly decrease the ionic conductivity and destabilize the electrode–electrolyte interface. This can lead to the formation of Zn dendrites, ultimately compromising the battery’s cycle life and safety [8–10]. To address these issues, exploring advanced bifunctional electrocatalysts with superior reaction kinetics, along with gel electrolytes that possess high ionic conductivity and good interfacial compatibility, is crucial for achieving large-scale implementations of ZABs. As a desirable candidate bifunctional catalyst for oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), cost-effective Co3O4 have attracted widespread attention although it suffers from inherent poor electrical conductivity that calls for enhancement [11,12]. Generally, there are two types of cobalt ions occupying distinct chemical environments in Co3O4: tetrahedral sites (1/3, CoTd) and octahedral sites (2/3, CoOh). Bulk Co3O4 shows a typical spinel structure (AB2O4) with the high-spin (HS) states of Co2+ ( 3 d 7 , e 4 t 2 3 ) at the tetrahedral (Td) sites, while the low-spin (LS) states of Co3+ ( 3 d 6 , t 2 g 6 e g 0 ) are at the Oh-sites [13–15]. As reported previously, the inherent catalytic performance of spinel oxides toward ORR and OER strongly is highly contingent on the occupation of eg orbitals of transition-metal cations at the Oh-sites, owing to the substantial overlap between the eg orbitals and the O 2p orbitals associated with the oxygen-related adsorbates [16–19]. With a moderate eg (∼1.0), the bifunctional activity and oxygen reaction kinetics can be enhanced via adjusting adsorption strength of oxygenated intermediates to active sites [20]. Furthermore, in the case of d-band theory, the shift of d-band in proximity to the Fermi level (EF) results in the lower occupation of the anti-bonding states, which is in correspondence with the greater adsorption of intermediates [21–23]. Thereby, modulating the Ed energy level and spin state of Co active site can be regarded as a promising approach to enhance the intrinsic activity of oxygen electrocatalytic for highly efficient ZABs. Recent studies have revealed that heteroatom doping can facilitate charge redistribution, allowing for the tuning of the band structure [24–26]. Vanadium, possessing plentiful vacant d-orbitals, exhibits excellent compatibility in binary and ternary spinel oxides (such as CoV2O4, CoV2-xFexO4, etc.), making it an attractive dopant for modifying the eg occupancy of Co3O4 [27,28]. On the other hand, the major challenge and opportunity involves how to develop solid-state electrolytes to optimize the storage performance of ZABs. Presently, a range of polymer substrates, like polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) [29,30], poly (acrylic acid) (PAA) [31,32], and polyacrylamide (PAM) [33,34], have been employed to fabricate solid-state electrolytes, demonstrating significant potential for application in ZABs. Nonetheless, these systems are still prone to battery failure, primarily due to substantial water loss resulting from the semi-open configuration of the air cathode in ZABs [35]. Meanwhile, they tend to lose their mechanical strength, particularly stretchability, when integrated with a strong alkaline electrolyte. Recently, a novel hydrogel electrolyte with a dual-network structure has been presented, featuring superior water retention, ionic conductivity, and mechanical flexibility [36,37]. More impressively, redox mediators (RMs) function as soluble charge catalysts are responsible for enhancing reaction kinetics and reducing the overpotential in both OER and ORR. Of the many RMs available, iodine species offers more favorable iodide/iodate redox kinetics at the cathode, which allows ZABs to operate in a sealed configuration and avoids electrolyte loss. Moreover, the presence of iodide ions also regulates the solvation structure of Zn ions, thus inhibiting the formation of dendrites and ensuring better anodic interfacial stability [38]. Taken together, the introduction of KI species into the dual network gel electrolyte would effectively addresses major issues faced by traditional ZABs and promotes the industrialization of ZABs. In light of the preceding research, we herein report an elaborate design of vanadium (V4+ and V5+) doped Co3O4 nanoframes (Co3O4 NFs) functioning as a bifunctional oxygen electrocatalyst for ZABs. The optimized V-Co3O4 NF catalyst reveals remarkable catalytic kinetics, characterized by a low overpotential of 340 mV (10 mA cm−2) for the OER and a high half-wave potential (E1/2) of 0.83 V for the ORR in an alkaline medium. Furthermore, a dual-network structured hydrogel electrolyte, consisting of sodium polyacrylate (PANa), cellulose (CE) and iodide (KI), is developed for solid-state zinc-air/iodide hybrid batteries. The constructed hybrid battery displays superior renewability, an extended cycling lifespan of 180 h, and achieves a high energy efficiency of 60.8 % in a sealed system. Through the analysis of theoretical calculations and experimental data, the reasons behind the enhanced performance of the hybrid battery are as follows: 1) The introduction of V atoms into the Co3O4 break the site symmetry, inducing the spin state transition of Co3+ at the Oh-sites from low spin state (LS, t 2 g 6 e g 0 ) to intermediate spin state (IS, t 2 g 5 e g 1 ) and optimizes the intrinsic activity; 2) Incorporating KI species not only improves the cathodic kinetics of the iodide/iodate redox process compared to oxygen electrocatalysis but also fine-tunes the solvation structure of zinc ions, ensuring better stability at the interface. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials Cobalt acetate (99.9 %), potassium hexacycobaltate (99 %), ammonia solution (AR, 28 ∼ 30 %), potassium hydroxide (85–87 %) and vanadium(III) chloride (VCl3, 99.0 %) were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich Co., Ltd. and used as received without any purification. The deionized water, characterized by a resistivity of 18.25 MΩ cm−1, underwent purification using a water ultrapure cation system. 2.2 Synthesis of Co PBA NCs and Co PBA NFs The Co3[Co(CN)6]2 nanocubes (Co PBA NCs) were prepared by following a precipitation process described in prior research. A typical synthesis procedure involved dissolving 1.2 mmol of cobalt acetate and 2.0 mmol of sodium citrate in 40 mL of H2O to yield solution A, and dissolving 0.8 mmol of potassium hexacycobaltate in 40 mL of H2O to yield solution B. Afterward, solution A and solution B were mixed using magnetic stirring for 2 h. Subsequently, the resulting mixture was left undisturbed for 24 h. The products were then obtained by filtration and then underwent a three-time washing process with H2O and 95 % ethanol, respectively. The Co PBA NCs, obtained in a pink powder form, were subjected to drying in a vacuum oven at 60 °C. In the typical Co PBA NFs synthesis procedure, 10 mL of ethanol, containing 20 mg of Co PBA NCs, was mixed with 20 mL of H2O containing 5 mL of ammonia solution (28 ∼ 30 %). The resulting mixture was stirred for 10 min at room temperature. The etched powder sample was collected by filtering and washed with abundant deionized water until the pH of filtrate reaching 7, and the collected Co PBA NFs were subjected to vacuum drying at 60 °C for 24 h. 2.3 Synthesis of V-Co PBA NFs 50 mg of the Co PBA NFs prepared beforehand were dispersed in 40 mL of ethanol, while 10 mg of VCl3 were dispersed in 10 mL of DI water. The above two solutions were stirred together for 4 h to complete the ion exchange reaction. The collected precipitates were centrifuged and washed three times with abundant deionized water and ethanol. The resulting V-Co PBA NFs were placed in a vacuum oven and dried at 60 °C for 24 h. The obtained V-Co PBA NFs were employed in the synthesis of V-doped Co3O4 NFs (V-Co3O4 NFs) 2.4 Synthesis of Co3O4 NFs and V-Co3O4 NFs In the typical synthesis, 50 mg Co PBA NFs were carefully loaded into a corundum boat at the center of tube furnace. The samples were heated in an argon atmosphere with a ramping rate of 2 ℃ min−1 to 500 ℃ and annealed for 2 h in a mixed 5 % oxygen/argon atmosphere. Co3O4 NFs were obtained as the final product. In the subsequent parallel experiments, the V-Co3O4 NFs were prepared under identical conditions. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Fabrication and structure characterizations of V-Co3O4 NFs The fabrication procedure of V-Co3O4 nanoframes (NFs) is schematically depicted in Fig. 1 a, which utilizes the pre-synthesized Co PBA nanocubes (NCs) as the sacrificial reactive template. Typically, the Co PBA NCs are initially fabricated via a facile coprecipitation process according to the previously reported protocol. An ammonia solution is then used for chemical etching to hollow out the interiors of Co PBA NCs, facilitating the formation of Co PBA NFs. As illustrated by the images (Fig. 1b–g) from scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM), the produced Co PBA NFs present a uniform hollow nanocube shape with a smooth surface, where cavities are located at the eight corners, forming an open structure with a hollow interior, and the wall thickness is approximately 80 nm. Such a nanoframe design can not only expose a greater number of defects, which is conducive to the subsequent substitution of vanadium ion, but also promote faster mass transport, as a consequence of the rapid infiltration of reactive species from electrolytes to catalytic sites on both external and internal surfaces. V-Co3O4 NFs are then obtained by implanting certain amount of V ion into the Co PBA NFs to form V-Co PBA NFs and subsequent pyrolysis in the mixed 5 % oxygen/argon atmosphere. SEM and TEM analyses indicate that V doping has an insignificant influence on the morphology of Co3O4, which shows a relative rough surface with a large number of small nanoparticles (Fig. 1h–k). The high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) images in Figs. 2 a–d and S1 indicate that the lattice spacing of the (3 1 1) facet for Co3O4 and V-Co3O4 catalysts are 0.24 nm and 0.26 nm, respectively. The increased lattice distance is ascribed to the partial substitution of Co3+ (0.545 Å, LS) with V4+ (0.580 Å), which has a larger ionic radius (note: V5+ has a similar radius of 0.540 Å as Co3+), paralleling phenomena observed in some binary spinel oxides [21,39]. The EDS mapping images presented in Fig. 2e–i verify the homogeneous distribution of Co and O elements within the V-Co3O4 NFs structure. As expected, all XRD peaks of Co PBA NFs and V-Co PBA NFs are similar to Co PBA NCs, verifying that the crystalline structure remains unchanged during the chemical etching and cation exchange processes (Fig. 2j). Additionally, organic ligands undergo complete oxidation during pyrolysis, releasing CO2 or NOx gases, and thus enriching the porous structure. The crystallographic structures of the as-synthesized Co3O4 NFs and V-Co3O4 NFs are further characterized. As depicted in Fig. 2k, Co3O4 with/without V doping possesses the same spinel-type structure [JCPDS no. 42-1467, space group: Fd3̅m (227), a = b = c = 8.0837 Å] [40]. Specifically, the primary diffraction peaks exhibit a shift towards lower angles, indicating the expansion of lattice parameters resulting from the substitution of V anions. This observation is in agreement with the high-resolution TEM analysis. To further confirm the effect of V-doping on spinel Co3O4, Raman measurements are performed on the as-prepared materials, as presented in Fig. 2l. For Co3O4, two obvious Raman peaks at 667 and 485 cm−1, assigning to the symmetrical vibration of octahedral sites (CoOh 3+sites, A1g) and tetrahedral site (CoTd 2+ sites, E g), respectively. Besides, compared with Raman modes of Co3O4, Raman peaks of V-Co3O4 indicate broadening and exhibits clear peak move toward higher wavenumber. More importantly, V-Co3O4 shows lower the I A1g/I Eg ratio (1.90) than that of Co3O4 NFs (1.99) after V doping. This result further confirms that V mainly occupies the CoOh 3+ sites of spinel Co3O4 NFs. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) technique is employed to analyze the surface elemental composition and valence states of V-Co3O4. Fig. S2 proves V element is efficiently doped into the Co3O4 NFs sample through comparing the full-scan XPS spectra of Co3O4 and V-Co3O4 NFs. Furthermore, the high-resolution V 2p spectrum reveals the presence of both high-valence V4+ and V5+ in V-Co3O4, which creates a surplus of vacant d-orbitals, leading to a strong electrostatic attraction. (Fig. 3 a) [23]. The high-resolution Co 2p spectra demonstrate that the peaks observed at 779.3 and 794.4 eV are indicative of the spin–orbit characteristics associated with Co3+, while the additional peaks at 781.1 and 796.4 eV are characteristic of Co2+ [41]. Note that the V-Co3O4 displays a positive shift of binding energy, the phenomenon is a consequence of the incorporation of V, resulting in the Co atoms of Co3O4 losing electrons in comparison to the pristine Co3O4. (Fig. 3b). Furthermore, the fitted Co 2p results also reveal that the ratio of Co3+/Co2+ decreases from 1.99 to 1.92 after V doping, confirming that the introduction of V mainly occupies the CoOh 3+ sites of spinel Co3O4. For both Co3O4 and V-Co3O4, their O 1s spectrum and electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) measurements consistently confirmed that V dopants trigger a large number of oxygen vacancies in V-Co3O4 (Fig. 3c and d). It has been demonstrated that oxygen vacancies play a significant role in enhancing the electronic conductivity of metal oxides, facilitating charge transfer, and also reducing the energy gap between the metal 3d and O 2p band centers, thereby increasing the covalent metal–oxygen bonding, which implies a shift of the oxide Fermi energy level below the O2/H2O redox energy, and finally an increase of the OER activity [42–44]. Further, the EPR spectrum of V-Co3O4 delivers the higher peak intensity than Co3O4, demonstrating the increased unpaired electrons in V-Co3O4, which is attributed to the electron spin configuration conversion of CoOh 3+. By analyzing N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms, it is observed that V-Co3O4 NFs exhibit a typical type-IV isotherm with a pronounced hysteresis loop in the medium pressure range, suggesting the presence of mesopores [45]. The corresponding pore size distribution (inset in Fig. 3e) reveals the average pore size is ca. 9.5 nm. The specific surface area is determined as 202.3 m2 g−1, such a hierarchical porous structure can promote the substance diffusion and mass transfer during catalytic processes. 3.2 Mechanism analysis The magnetic properties of spinel oxides exhibit a strong dependence on their spin states, with specific spin configurations dictating the localized magnetic moment contributions at atomic sites. To determine the preferable electronic state of V-Co3O4 for the oxygen catalytic reaction, the temperature-dependent magnetization characterization with an applied field of H = 500 Oe is taken to get insights into the eg occupancy of Co3+ at the Oh-sites. As illustrated in Fig. 3f, above 55 K, the magnetic susceptibility (χ) derived from the paramagnetic data (χ = M/H) follows the Curie-Weiss law: χ = C/(T − Θ), in which C is the Curie constant and Θ is the Curie-Weiss temperature. The effective paramagnetic moment (μeff) calculated from the fitting results can be used to study the eg orbital filling number through μ eff 2 = g 2 J ( J + 1 ) μ B 2 (Experimental Section, Supporting Information). As shown in Fig. 3g, the calculated μeff value for V-Co3O4 is about 3.65 μB, which corresponds to the Co3+ with 50.5 % HS and 49.5 % LS states, affording an eg orbital filling number of ≈1.010, while the value for Co3O4 is ≈0.473. The increase in μeff correlated with the occupation of eg states of Co, which can be attributed to V doping. For the as-prepared Co3O4, the calculated μeff value shows a distinctive discrepancy from the bulk Co3O4. Such a phenomenon may originate from the size effect in nanosized materials and/ or site exchange between Td-site and Oh-site atoms, which easily occurs at high temperatures arising from thermal activation, rendering a locally mixed structure of spinel and inverse spinel (Fig. 3h) [21,46]. The optimized eg occupancy can balance the adsorption energies of intermediates during ORR&OER to improve the intrinsic activity of the material. And thus V-Co3O4 holds great potential as a promising bifunctional oxygen electrocatalyst for ZABs. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were further performed to confirm the formation energy in the cases of V substitutes in different Co sites. As displayed in Figs. 4 a and S3, the V atom, replacing CoOh site in Co3O4, is more stable (−347.1 eV) than that of substituting CoTd site (−346.5 eV). Therefore, the following theoretical analyses are based on the former. Furthermore, the density of states (DOS) of Co3O4 with/without V doping is conducted. Co3O4 exhibits p-type semiconductor properties with a wide band gap of 1.45 eV. However, there is a continuous density of states near the Fermi level in V-Co3O4, demonstrating enhanced electrical conductivity. Meanwhile, the d-band center was correspondingly modulated from −6.6 eV in the Co3O4 to −4.6 eV in the V-Co3O4 (Fig. 4b–d). Besides, the charge density of Co atoms near the doped V atom is lower than that of the pristine Co3O4 (Fig. 4e), which are consistent with the results of XPS. All of the above analyses shed light on the fact that V-element doping enhances the electronic conductivity and upshift d-band center, demonstrating a fast adsorption capacity toward the different adsorption intermediates during the ORR and OER process. Theoretically, the ORR and OER electrocatalytic activity is significantly influenced by the Gibbs free energy barriers of the rate-determining step on the electrocatalyst surfaces. For comparison, Co3O4 (3 1 1) and V-Co3O4 (3 1 1) species were used as models for the calculations. The binding energies of reaction intermediates involved in ORR and OER, including O*, OH* and OOH* species, were calculated for Co sites of the structural model (Figs. 4h and S4). As can be seen from the free energy pathways of the ORR process in Fig. 4f, all the electron transfer steps of V-Co3O4 electrode will carry out spontaneously at a U value of below 0.65 V, indicating all reaction steps are exothermic. The whole process is dominated by the rate-determining step: OH* + e− = OH− + *. The results indicated higher ORR electrochemical activity of the V-doped catalyst relative to pristine Co3O4. For OER, the largest potential step at the equilibrium potential (1.82 V) suggested the rate-determining step with the corresponding overpotential listed in Fig. 4g. Therefore, the V doping catalyst can effectively enhance the intrinsic activity of Co3O4 catalyst by reducing the free energy at ORR/OER rate-determining steps. 3.3 Electrochemical ORR/OER activities Based on the magnetic measurements and DFT calculation, introducing V atoms to the Co3O4 enhances the spin state of Co3+ and then facilitates the absorption of O2, the attractive electrochemical performance of V-Co3O4 NFs is expected. As a validation, the bifunctional electrocatalytic performance of V-Co3O4 with different V doping amounts was evaluated by a variety of electrochemical methods. The electrocatalytic ORR and OER performance were tested in 0.1 M KOH electrolyte saturated with O2 in three-electrode configuration. As a comparison, commercial Pt/C and pure Co3O4 were also assessed under identical condition. To examine the electrochemical performance of the catalyst for ORR, we performed CV measurement in 0.1 M O2- and N2-saturated KOH solutions. As shown in Fig. S5, no other Faradic current appeared for all of the samples in the N2-saturated electrolyte. In contrast, obvious ORR peaks appear in O2-saturated KOH, indicating that as-prepared samples can effectively catalyze ORR. Moreover, the reduction peak of V-Co3O4 is more positive than that of pure Co3O4. In order to further evaluate the ORR performance of the investigated catalyst, LSV curves were acquired in the O2-saturated electrolyte. As demonstrated in Fig. 5 a, V-Co3O4 exhibits outstanding ORR activity with the onset potential (E onset = 0.99 V), half-wave potential (E 1/2 = 0.83 V) and limiting current density (j L = −6.67 mA m−2), significantly superior to pure Co3O4 (E onset = 0.82 V, E 1/2 = 0.69 V, j L = −4.54 mA m−2) and even comparable with commercial Pt/C (E onset = 0.98 V, E 1/2 = 0.84 V, j L = −5.93 mA m−2). Further, the Tafel slope (68.2 mV dec-1) verify its faster reaction kinetics and better electron transfer efficiency for ORR (Fig. 5b). For a deeper understanding of the catalyst kinetics and reaction pathway, the LSV curves of as-prepared samples at different rotation rates (400 rpm–2025 rpm) were performed (Fig. S6-7). The limiting current density of V-Co3O4 gradually increases with the rotational speed, and the corresponding Koutecky-Levich plots exhibit excellent linearity, indicating that the ORR is diffusion-limited and follows a first-order reaction kinetics [47]. Rotating ring-disk electrode (RRDE) tests are also carried out for V-Co3O4 and Pt/C to investigate the electron transfer number (n) and hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) yield. As Fig. 5c illustrates, V-Co3O4 present high 4-electron ORR selectivity as n was calculated to be 3.75 with a H2O2 yield below 10 % over the potential window of 0.2–0.8 V. Direct four-electron reaction suppress the generation of H2O2, which in turn improves the cyclic stability of the catalyst. As expected, the chronoamperometry test shows the current density of V-Co3O4 retained up to 83.2 % of the original value after continuous operation for 24 h (Fig. 5d). For OER, V-Co3O4 reaches a current density of 10 mA m−2 at the lowest overpotential (340 mV) compared to other control samples (Fig. 5e). Further, it also exhibits a smaller Tafel slope of 67.3 mV dec−1, signifying its superior OER kinetics (Fig. S8). The improved reaction kinetics may be attributed to two aspects: an accelerated charge transfer rate between the electrolyte and electrocatalysts and an increased electrochemically active area. The above speculation can be confirmed by electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) and double-layer capacitance (Cdl, Fig. S9). As demonstrated in Fig. 5g and h, V-Co3O4 possesses a lower charge-transfer resistance (Rct) of 11.2 and a higher Cdl of 11.6 mF cm−2. Besides evaluating the electrochemical activity, the durability was also evaluated. The chronopotentiometric tests reveal that V-Co3O4 shows excellent electrochemical stability with the current retention of 96.9 % during the extended electrolysis for 12h at a constant overpotential of 340 mV (inset of Fig. 5h), which was also confirmed by the basically identical LSV profiles before and after 2000 continuous cycles. More importantly, the influence of V doping amounts on both OER and ORR performance is also investigated (Fig. S10 and Table S4). Note that with the increase of V doping amount, the electrocatalytic OER/ORR performance shows a trend of increasing first and then decreasing, including overpotential for OER, and jL for ORR. Besides, the half-wave potential (E1/2) of ORR displays a trend of decreasing first and then increasing and finally decreasing. To sum up, V-Co3O4 (V6-Co3O4) has the best bifunctional OER/ORR activities, indicating that over-doping of V will inhibit the ORR/OER performance of Co3O4. The overall ORR/OER bifunctional activities were assessed by the potential gap (ΔE) between OER and ORR (ΔE = Ej=10 − E1/2 ), thermodynamically, a small ΔE value represents less efficiency loss and preferable reversibility. Remarkably, the ΔE of V-Co3O4 is 0.74 V (Fig. 5i), superior to the majority of reported bifunctional catalysts and comparable with the mixed commercial noble catalyst (ΔE = 0.70 V). 3.4 RZAB performance of V-Co3O4 To further verify that V-Co3O4 catalyst can be used as bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts for practical applications and the role of iodine species in improved performance, a sandwich-type rechargeable ZAB was constructed (Figs. 6 a and S11). Here, the air electrode was fabricated via coating the V-Co3O4 on a carbon cloth, while a zinc plate and PANa/CE/KI gel served as the anode and electrolyte, respectively. We first analyzed the water absorption capacity of PANa/CE/KI hydrogels. As shown in Fig. 6b, as-prepared PANa/CE/KI hydrogels reached a swelling equilibrium after 16h immersion in KOH electrolyte and their uptake capacity reached 5.8 times the initial weight after 24 h. By comparison, the adsorption capacity of PANa gel is only 3.4 times the weight of its own in the same time. The PANa/CE/KI hydrogels also showed a very good water retention capacity, which eventually reached 82 % when fully exposed to air (Fig. 6c). As anticipated, potassium and iodine ions enhance ionic transport properties, ion conductivity of PANa/CE/KI electrolyte was determined to be 149.3 mS cm−1 by electrochemical impedance measurements (Fig. 6d). Additionally, tensile tests exhibit that PANa/CE/KI hydrogels possess a 774.9 % strain and high mechanical strength of 17.64 kPa, further emphasizing the key role of cellulose in the process (Fig. 6e). As illustrated in Fig. S12, the open-circuit voltage of V-Co3O4-based ZAB with PANa/CE/KI hydrogel electrolyte is measured to be 1.42 V. Fig. 6f shows the discharge curves of the above battery, and the corresponding peak power density can reach 132.7 mW cm−2. Moreover, the discharge performance of as-prepared ZAB at different current densities were tested, it can be found that the discharge voltage plateau is quite stable within 1–50 mA m−2, and when the current is rapidly switched to 1 mA m−2, the voltage responds quickly to the initial value, indicating high-rate capability and excellent reversibility (Fig. 6g). More importantly, the sandwich-type flexible battery demonstrates high mechanical stability (a stable charging/discharging platform) even when folded at different angles (Fig. 6h). To investigate the mechanism behind the performance of above RZAB, we initially assembled sealed cells and semi-open structures for comparison by long-term galvanostatic discharge measurements. As presented in Fig. 7 a-b, the sealed PANa/CE-based ZAB displays poor stability than that of the semi-open state at 5 mA m−2 with a duration of 20 min per cycle, further demonstrating the necessity of the semi-open state for the cathodic oxygen reaction in the absence of KI additives. Surprisingly, the sealed PANa/CE/KI-based ZAB could maintain a stable lifespan up to 180 h for 360 cycles with negligible polarization decay (roundtrip efficiency from 65.6 % to 60.8 %), the above result demonstrated the coexistence of oxygen redox and iodide/iodate conversion reactions in Zn-air/iodide hybrid battery. We then investigated the electrochemical reactions in the different electrolytes with a three-electrode system (Figs. 7c and S14). The OER achieves 10 mAcm−2 at 1.57 V (vs. RHE) in the KOH solution. However, iodide ion oxidation occurs at 1.37 V (vs. RHE) in KOH/KI solution in the presence of O2. This potential difference of agrees well with the charging voltage difference in PANa/CE- and PANa/CE/KI-based batteries. Therefore, corresponding to a higher thermodynamic oxygen redox at 1.23 V vs RHE, the iodide/iodate redox at 1.09 V vs RHE provides potential for pairing Zn anodes and assembling high-efficiency batteries. Subsequently, we further confirmed the electrochemical reaction processes by ultraviolet–visible (UV/Vis) spectra. As shown in Fig. 7d and e, a strong absorption peak at 345 nm attributed to iodate ions gradually strengthens with the charging process and diminishes with the discharging process, therefore, the cathodic oxygen could be replaced by iodide ion/iodate redox reaction [46,48]. The physicochemical robustness of V-Co3O4 is further evidenced by XRD and TEM characterizations (Fig. S15), illustrating inherent structural stability of V-Co3O4 during the long-lasting cycling test. 4 Conclusion In summary, we confirm that modulating the Ed energy level and spin state of Co active site can be regarded as a promising approach to enhance the intrinsic activity of oxygen electrocatalytic for highly efficient ZABs. The introduction of V atoms into the Co3O4 break the site symmetry, inducing the spin state transition of Co3+ at the Oh-sites from low spin state (LS, t 2 g 6 e g 0 ) to intermediate spin state (IS, t 2 g 5 e g 1 ). Simultaneously, density functional theory calculations further demonstrate spin-state modulation reduces the energy gap between the metal 3d and O 2p band centers, which balance the adsorption/desorption of oxygen intermediates and further enhance the oxygen reaction kinetics. Consequently, in comparison to pristine Co3O4, V-Co3O4 exhibits a small potential gap value of 0.74 V. Additionally, the introduction of KI in solid-state electrolyte provides a more thermodynamically favorable pathway. Thereby, the constructed hybrid battery displays superior renewability, an extended cycling lifespan of 180 h, and achieves a high energy efficiency of 60.8 % in a sealed system, offering a promising power source for the next-generation electronics. coredata.dc:description: The rational construction of bifunctional air cathode electrocatalysts with high intrinsic reversibility and durability is critical for practical applications of rechargeable solid Zn-air batteries (ZABs). Unlike traditional nanomorphology construction methods, this work focus on the enhancement of intrinsic catalytic properties by heteroatom vanadium doping strategy to modulate the spin state of Co3+ ions active sites at the octahedral sites of spinel Co3O4. The magnetic measurements and the theoretical calculation consistently reveal that V atom incorporation induce the spin state transition of Co3+ from low spin state (LS, t 2 g 6 e g 0 ) to intermediate spin state (IS, t 2 g 5 e g 1 ), and reduces the energy gap between the Co 3d and O 2p band centers, which balance the adsorption/desorption of oxygen intermediates and further enhance the oxygen reaction kinetics. Consequently, the optimized V-Co3O4 demonstrated a small potential gap value of 0.74 V between the ORR half-wave potential and the OER potential at 10 mA m−2. More importantly, the introduction of KI in solid-state electrolyte provides a more thermodynamically favorable pathway. Thereby, the assembled ZAB displays excellent long-term durability (180 h), offering a promising power source for the next-generation electronics. This work advances a feasible design concept to tune catalytic activity for ZABs by optimizing the spin states and developing novel solid-state electrolytes.
